Iron Ore.--We have seen specim., &c
Iron Ore from the Gun Stock Mountain i
this state, of so good a quality that 100 lhs
OF It. as dug from the mountain yielded 7slh
OF best wrought iron. The place from
whence this is obtained is within three miles
OF Lake Winnipisiogee; the ore abounds in
every part Of the mountain of which trials
have been made; and appearances warrant
the conclusion, that the whole ridge, extend
ing nearly twenty miles, is little less than
mass OF ore. Iron can be wrought from
these mines with great facility, and to anv
extent; and would afford profitable article
OF trade, It water conveyance was omen
from the lake to the sea coast,--,N. Ifamt
Jour.

AN ACT to grant certain quantity Of land


to the State Of Indiana, for the purpose Of ad
r ing said State in opening u Canal to connect


the waters of the Wabash River with those


of Lake Erie.


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House of
REPRESENTATIVES Of the United States Of ~

ana, for the purpose of aiding the State in opeu-
ing canal to unite the waters OF the Naba h riv-
er with those of Lake Eric, quantity Of
land equal to one half of FIVE sections in width,
on each side Of said canal, and reservng each
alternate section to the United States, to be Sc
lected by the Commissioner of the Land Office,
under the direction of the President of the Unit
ed States, from one end of the said Canal to the
other; and the said lands shall be subject TO the
disposal Of the Legislature of the said State, for
the purpose aforesaid, and no other Pror'ded,
That the said canal, when completed, shall be,
and forever remain, public highway for the Use
of the Government of the U. States, free from a.
ny toll, or other charge, whatever, for any prop
erty OF the u States. or persons in their service,
passing through the same. Provided, that said
canal shall be commenced within five wears and
completed in twenty years, or the State shall be
bound to pay to the United tates the amount oi
any lands previously sold, and that the title te
purchasers under the State shall be valid.

AN ACT TO authorize the importation Of Brandy,
in casks Of capacity not less than fifteen %al-


Ions and the expectation Of the same for the


benefit of draw back OF the duties


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House II
REPRESENTATIVES IF the UnRed STATES of ~
merica in Congress- assembled, That, from
and after the passage of this act, brandy may be
imported into the United States in casks Of ca
pacity not less than fifteen gallons, any thing in
any law to the contrary notwithstanding: Prerid-
ed, homeuer, That all the provisions of existing
laws, not inconsistent with this act, relating TO the
Importation Of foreign spirits, be complied with:
find prou.ded further, That all brandy imported
in casks of capacity less than ninety gallons,
shall be deposited, at the expense and risk Of the
importer, in such public or other warehouses, as
shall be designated by the Collector or Survey
or, for the port where the same shall be landed,
and shall be removed thereirom III the manner
prescribed By an act entitled san act for provid-
inE tor the deposite OF wines and distilled spirits
in public archousrs, and for other purposes. /"


SEC. 9. IND be II .fltrtdtr enacted, That
brandy imported in casks Of a capacity not less
than fifteen gallons, may be exported for the
benefit Of drawback OF the duties which shall
have been paid thereon; and the exporter or cx
porters Of brandy so imported, shall be entitled
to receive debenture or dcbenturcs, for the a.
mount Of such drawback, agrccablv to the exist,
ng laws; and all acts now ia force regulating the
expectation ofsplrts, and the allowance and pay
incnt of drawbacks and debcnturcs, shall 30
deemed applicable TO brandy, the Importation oi
which ls permitted by this act


SEC. 5. ,dnd be IL further ensctea, Tina,
this act shall continue in force for tile period o
three years, and no longer.


Approved March 2, 1897.

Letter from Jack Tar 10 his Uucle san,


Dear Uncle-I have made a nun,bsr &c
voyages in your good ship Union, and adj.
mire her accommodations, her sailing. and
the good order which has usually prevailed
on board, but from what have lately over
heard. understand that some mart of ou,
crew are clamorous for change of officers
which II effected may produce trouble -Tt
appears that their design is to turn the pres-
ent riot out of his birth, and make a puot
ont OF the Gunner, who is as bold
man as ever pointed a cannon; 5ut boldness
is not the qualification for which Pilot i
TO be most valued; and hope you will cx-
cuse me. Uncle, it ! say that in the charac-
terstics Of Pilot, an ounce of circumspec
tion Is worth more than pound of boldness
1T they could both be weighed. Your Pi-
lot has long studied to make himself ac-
qualnted with our native shoals. and with
foreign straits. and his attention is so deyot-
ed to the Chart and Compass, that when
turn in at night, | feel as safe as if were
landed on Terra frma. Since have been
on board the Union, her guns have rarely
been fired. except for rejoicing, and hone
they never will be heard for any other pur.
pose; but if your Gunner should be showed
into the Pilots place, his fondness for the
Cannon's sound, may possibly lead him to
indnlge his favorite amusement, at the haz-
ard Of the ships Company MY fears have
led me to make these remarks, which hope
you will excuse from


Your respectful nephew.


JACK TAR.

he streets Of Havana are very narrow,
and lowest III the centre. The side walks
are in proportion; and as little attention is
paid to keeping any part ofthe pavement
in repair, it is difficult to walk with ease. In
addition to this, the part of the city near to
the wharf is usually crowded with mules,
carts and negroes.


The most prominent public building that
meets the eye after landing. is the Govern
ment house, CASA de Gobierno) This
fronts on a square, called Plaza de Ermas.-
is two stories high, supported in front By ten
heavy pillars and arches, and occupies a
square of nearly 800 feet. The lower a.
partment is used for the various civil and
military Offices Of the government; in the
centre is large gate opening to the court
and the upper story is occupied by the Cap.
tain General and his officers. The puhiic
cunA IN 1927.

''A girl, named skinner, fourteen years ofage,
residing in White-street Cartcr.gatc, in this
town, had this operation performed, on Wedncs-
day, February IA; being the first time il has
been successfully attempted, She was attac ked
with rheumatism last January, at which time,
Mr.. Jowett, the surgeon to ST. Marys parish,
discovered, bv the use of the stethoscope, that
the pericar3'uM and lining memhrlncc of the
heart, were inAamed lkewisc.-By very ac-
i've measures, the severity OF the complaint was
subdura, aud She appeared to be recovering, but
the stcthoscopc conjoned with other signs, midi
Gated that considerable efusion, or tlropsey, had
taken place in the pericsrdium. On the 18th
of February, She became much worse, and on
tile fourteenth was so bad, that i, was evident
she coul not survive tiie night, unless some re-
het WAS afforded, The operation having been
previously proposed, was then consented TO,
and was performed by Mr.. Iowctt the same at
ternoon, in the presence Of Dr. Manson, (the
consulting physiciln, an assistant, and the pa
tents friends. II WAS at first intended to have
drawn The fluid out by means Of syringe pump,
fitted with proper apparatus; but an accidental
circumstance occasoncd, what has suce proved
a mtteral Improvement, VIZ. the evacuation OF
thr fluid into the left cavity ofthc chest, which
beng IN healthy state, absorbed i in a very
sl'ort tnne. Within twelve hours after the op.
crt'iou there was manifest improvements ana
We AZ" happy to say, that although She still rc
mlns ma very weak and exhausted state, con.
siderable hopes OF recovery are entertained.

PrtridgeS' EFgs i III our paper Of tlc
lJth inst. vas = short paragraph, stating thai
a young woman mad been committed to pris-
on III Nottlnghams fr taking a t.w

ment excited the notice Of one az at;- read

'I4ast summer Mary Marshall Young NO.
man of good character, was wedding il a
field, along with some other women, WHEN
4 they found nest containing some eggs. AS
they did not suppose there was any harm in
taking the eggs OF wild bird, they agreed
70 divide thrm. and AS She happened to have
a basket with her they were put in it and
carried home, when their labor was over.--
l'he circumstance coming to the know ledge
Of the game keeper, he LAID an information
against her, and the poor glrl finding that
she had committed an offence against the
game laws, and fearful Of the consequences,
left her home and went to Nottingham


where She was taken into the service ot Nh
r Swanwick OF the Kings Head lavcrn.--


Here her conduct was quite in accordance


with her previous good character, md il
this Situation she might have remained, with


credit to herself aud 70 the entire satiStdCt
! ton of her employer But Justice, it seems
# was not satisfied, no eXpiaton had beer
/, made for the hor,ibc crime Of taking tw,
h Or three eggs found in field; and the piac,
= OF her retreat being discovered. she wa
:, dragged away from her comfortable situa
t tion, AMI being taken before the Rev Mr.
e Lowe, OF Bingham, and the Rev. Mr.. Beau
e mont Of East Britgeford,. this respectable
II Young woman was by them committed TO
I, three months to the Southwell Honsc Of Cor
;, rection!"- Manchester Gazette.

Iron Ore.--We have seen specim., &c
Iron Ore from the Gun Stock Mountain i
this state, of so good a quality that 100 lhs
OF It. as dug from the mountain yielded 7slh
OF best wrought iron. The place from
whence this is obtained is within three miles
OF Lake Winnipisiogee; the ore abounds in
every part Of the mountain of which trials
have been made; and appearances warrant
the conclusion, that the whole ridge, extend
ing nearly twenty miles, is little less than
mass OF ore. Iron can be wrought from
these mines with great facility, and to anv
extent; and would afford profitable article
OF trade, It water conveyance was omen
from the lake to the sea coast,--,N. Ifamt
Jour.

full articles.headline: [PcsLIc-No. 39.3
full articles.article:
AN ACT to grant certain quantity Of land


to the State Of Indiana, for the purpose Of ad
r ing said State in opening u Canal to connect


the waters of the Wabash River with those


of Lake Erie.


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House of
REPRESENTATIVES Of the United States Of ~
nlerica in Congress assembled, That there
be, and hereby is, granted to the State Of In'l,-
ana, for the purpose of aiding the State in opeu-
ing canal to unite the waters OF the Naba h riv-
er with those of Lake Eric, quantity Of
land equal to one half of FIVE sections in width,
on each side Of said canal, and reservng each
alternate section to the United States, to be Sc
lected by the Commissioner of the Land Office,
under the direction of the President of the Unit
ed States, from one end of the said Canal to the
other; and the said lands shall be subject TO the
disposal Of the Legislature of the said State, for
the purpose aforesaid, and no other Pror'ded,
That the said canal, when completed, shall be,
and forever remain, public highway for the Use
of the Government of the U. States, free from a.
ny toll, or other charge, whatever, for any prop
erty OF the u States. or persons in their service,
passing through the same. Provided, that said
canal shall be commenced within five wears and
completed in twenty years, or the State shall be
bound to pay to the United tates the amount oi
any lands previously sold, and that the title te
purchasers under the State shall be valid.


SEC. 2. find Be IL farther enacted, That, 81
soon as the ioute of the said canal shall be locat
I'd and agreed on by the said State, it shall bt
lie duty Of the Governor thereof or such othe

full articles.headline: [PrnLIc-No. 38. i
full articles.article:
AN ACT TO authorize the importation Of Brandy,
in casks Of capacity not less than fifteen %al-


Ions and the expectation Of the same for the


benefit of draw back OF the duties


Be ii enacted By the Senate and House II
REPRESENTATIVES IF the UnRed STATES of ~
merica in Congress- assembled, That, from
and after the passage of this act, brandy may be
imported into the United States in casks Of ca
pacity not less than fifteen gallons, any thing in
any law to the contrary notwithstanding: Prerid-
ed, homeuer, That all the provisions of existing
laws, not inconsistent with this act, relating TO the
Importation Of foreign spirits, be complied with:
find prou.ded further, That all brandy imported
in casks of capacity less than ninety gallons,
shall be deposited, at the expense and risk Of the
importer, in such public or other warehouses, as
shall be designated by the Collector or Survey
or, for the port where the same shall be landed,
and shall be removed thereirom III the manner
prescribed By an act entitled san act for provid-
inE tor the deposite OF wines and distilled spirits
in public archousrs, and for other purposes. /"


SEC. 9. IND be II .fltrtdtr enacted, That
brandy imported in casks Of a capacity not less
than fifteen gallons, may be exported for the
benefit Of drawback OF the duties which shall
have been paid thereon; and the exporter or cx
porters Of brandy so imported, shall be entitled
to receive debenture or dcbenturcs, for the a.
mount Of such drawback, agrccablv to the exist,
ng laws; and all acts now ia force regulating the
expectation ofsplrts, and the allowance and pay
incnt of drawbacks and debcnturcs, shall 30
deemed applicable TO brandy, the Importation oi
which ls permitted by this act


SEC. 5. ,dnd be IL further ensctea, Tina,
this act shall continue in force for tile period o
three years, and no longer.


Approved March 2, 1897.

full articles.headline: From the Boston Centinel.
full articles.article:
Letter from Jack Tar 10 his Uucle san,


Dear Uncle-I have made a nun,bsr &c
voyages in your good ship Union, and adj.
mire her accommodations, her sailing. and
the good order which has usually prevailed
on board, but from what have lately over
heard. understand that some mart of ou,
crew are clamorous for change of officers
which II effected may produce trouble -Tt
appears that their design is to turn the pres-
ent riot out of his birth, and make a puot
ont OF the Gunner, who is as bold
man as ever pointed a cannon; 5ut boldness
is not the qualification for which Pilot i
TO be most valued; and hope you will cx-
cuse me. Uncle, it ! say that in the charac-
terstics Of Pilot, an ounce of circumspec
tion Is worth more than pound of boldness
1T they could both be weighed. Your Pi-
lot has long studied to make himself ac-
qualnted with our native shoals. and with
foreign straits. and his attention is so deyot-
ed to the Chart and Compass, that when
turn in at night, | feel as safe as if were
landed on Terra frma. Since have been
on board the Union, her guns have rarely
been fired. except for rejoicing, and hone
they never will be heard for any other pur.
pose; but if your Gunner should be showed
into the Pilots place, his fondness for the
Cannon's sound, may possibly lead him to
indnlge his favorite amusement, at the haz-
ard Of the ships Company MY fears have
led me to make these remarks, which hope
you will excuse from


Your respectful nephew.


JACK TAR.

are--how-yo,l--marr With a long breath

have heard since with infinite regret, tfat
my uncle is crazy. That whenever lie goes n
the sun he protests that the shallow OF Timothy
0ciheait is missing, and that the devil IN the
shape OF dandy putsucs him at every step, and
always keeps some how between him and his


awful, portly, old fashioned shade, II IS sad
news, Mcssrs. Editors-and YOU will pity, with
me, the sorrows Of the poor old man.

cunA IN 1927.

LEI TER IL
full articles.article:
he streets Of Havana are very narrow,
and lowest III the centre. The side walks
are in proportion; and as little attention is
paid to keeping any part ofthe pavement
in repair, it is difficult to walk with ease. In
addition to this, the part of the city near to
the wharf is usually crowded with mules,
carts and negroes.


The most prominent public building that
meets the eye after landing. is the Govern
ment house, CASA de Gobierno) This
fronts on a square, called Plaza de Ermas.-
is two stories high, supported in front By ten
heavy pillars and arches, and occupies a
square of nearly 800 feet. The lower a.
partment is used for the various civil and
military Offices Of the government; in the
centre is large gate opening to the court
and the upper story is occupied by the Cap.
tain General and his officers. The puhiic

The Lonton Morning Chronicle has the
following anecdote, which is At once melan-
choly and laughable Amin Intelligent gentle
man, accompanying medical friend IN his
rounds through Southwark, he entered one
Of those ~rrtchcd abodcs in which the Irish
crowd together The man had received AN
injury, and was unable to work two
children were sprawling about and two large
pigs were also inmates Of the apartment
why do YOU not sell the pigs to assist you!''
was question put to the wife. "Ooh, Sir, .
"the pigs belong to the landlord, we get the
room at less rent, for taking 10 the pigs as
,ulgers'

AN ACT to extend the time of issuing and 10.
eating Military Land Warrants TO officers and
soldiers Of the Revolutionary army.


Ben enacted 5y t4s .Seaafs ard House IF
Representatives. of The UnHri States II a
marica ii Congress assembled, That the
time limited by the seconl section of the actap-
proved the twenty-tourth day oflehruary, one
thousand eight hundred and nineteen, for ssu
ing Military Land Warrants to the officers and
soldiers of the Revolutionary army, shall be eX-
tended to the fourth day of March, one thou
sand eight hundred and thirty; and the time for
locating the INDICATED warrants shall be extend
ed till the first day of October thereafter.


Approved March ,, 1897.

BE il enacted bv tie Senate and House of

meriea in Congress assembled, That the

unmarryng all those who wish to be unmar-

self to pay the National Debt in three
years"

full articles.headline:
Operation Of Tipping ne Pttiealdinm, o. Bag,


contaiatHg Tie Htdr!.
full articles.article:
''A girl, named skinner, fourteen years ofage,
residing in White-street Cartcr.gatc, in this
town, had this operation performed, on Wedncs-
day, February IA; being the first time il has
been successfully attempted, She was attac ked
with rheumatism last January, at which time,
Mr.. Jowett, the surgeon to ST. Marys parish,
discovered, bv the use of the stethoscope, that
the pericar3'uM and lining memhrlncc of the
heart, were inAamed lkewisc.-By very ac-
i've measures, the severity OF the complaint was
subdura, aud She appeared to be recovering, but
the stcthoscopc conjoned with other signs, midi
Gated that considerable efusion, or tlropsey, had
taken place in the pericsrdium. On the 18th
of February, She became much worse, and on
tile fourteenth was so bad, that i, was evident
she coul not survive tiie night, unless some re-
het WAS afforded, The operation having been
previously proposed, was then consented TO,
and was performed by Mr.. Iowctt the same at
ternoon, in the presence Of Dr. Manson, (the
consulting physiciln, an assistant, and the pa
tents friends. II WAS at first intended to have
drawn The fluid out by means Of syringe pump,
fitted with proper apparatus; but an accidental
circumstance occasoncd, what has suce proved
a mtteral Improvement, VIZ. the evacuation OF
thr fluid into the left cavity ofthc chest, which
beng IN healthy state, absorbed i in a very
sl'ort tnne. Within twelve hours after the op.
crt'iou there was manifest improvements ana
We AZ" happy to say, that although She still rc
mlns ma very weak and exhausted state, con.
siderable hopes OF recovery are entertained.


Atiiagtan9 Jo.gHql

'I4ast summer Mary Marshall Young NO.

l'he circumstance coming to the know ledge

II Young woman was by them committed TO

The Harrisburg Chronicle saws, tho work
on the eastern section Of the Pennsylvania
Canal is advancing rapidly. The greater
part of the excavation between the mouth
of the Juniata and the Swatara is Effected,
though only small portion is entirely com
pleted. The bridge and lock building is
! carried on with spirit. The large basin near
| Harrisburg is faished.
